Sample.Title: wild-type 1 hour (1) slide 1

Channel.Source: time course sample harvested after 1 hour of glucose to acetate shift
Channel.Label: Cy3

Channel.Source: reference sample harvested immediately prior to glucose to acetate shift
Channel.Label: Cy5

Sample.Description: Ratio reported in the database is reference/time course sample. However, ratio reported in paper is time course sample/reference sample.

Column.Name: VALUE
Column.Description: normalized log base 10 ratio of reference/time course sample (cy5/cy3)

Series.Title: BW25113 glucose to acetate transition
Series.Summary: In bacterial adaptation to the dynamic environment, metabolic genes are typically thought to be the executors, whereas global transcription regulators are regarded as the decision makers. Although the feedback from metabolic consequence is believed to be important, much less is understood. This work demonstrates that the gluconeogenic genes in Escherichia coli, ppsA, sfcA, and maeB, provide a feedback loop to the global regulator, CRP, in carbon source transition. Disruption of one of the gluconeogenic pathways has no phenotype in balanced growth, but causes a significant delay in the diauxic transition from glucose to acetate. To investigate the underlying mechanism, we measured the transcriptome profiles during the transition using DNA microarray, and Network Component Analysis was employed to obtain the transcription factor activities. Results showed that one of the global regulators, CRP, was insufficiently activated during the transition in the ppsA deletion mutant. Indeed, addition of cAMP partially rescued the delay in transition. These results suggest that the gluconeogenic flux to phosphoenolpyruvate is important for full activation of adenylate cyclase through phosphorylated enzyme IIAglu of the phosphotransferase system. Reduction of this flux causes insufficient activation of CRP and a global metabolic deficiency, which exemplifies a significant feedback interaction from metabolism to the global regulatory system. Keywords: Time course
Series.Overall-Design: Cells were grown up in M9 glucose media until mid log phase, then harvested and transitioned into M9 acetate media. Samples were taken immediately prior to transition to acetate (reference sample) and at 5, 15, 30, 60, 120, 180, 240, 300, and 360 minutes after transition.
